Hello EOS Hi EOS Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever. EOS I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany EOS So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss. EOS This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks. EOS No, my family all moved from the area.  The nearest is now half a country away and hasn't spoken to me in over ten years. EOS It's been... interesting. EOS Ahhh... I hate to be that guy, but I really don't have that many friends.  I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...) EOS I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant. EOS And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was. EOS I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known. EOS I think they forgot about me. EOS The only one I still have contact with is my mother. EOS I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it. EOS I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer. EOS I'm just thankful I have had her this long EOS That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others. EOS Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed... EOS there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do. EOS The look of pride in his face was priceless. EOS The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team. EOS I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language. EOS I am the first signing member of the church. EOS 2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation. EOS I joined just over ten years ago. EOS My church is my anchor. EOS My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted. EOS My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry. EOS If you mean me, I'm male. EOS But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign. EOS Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling. EOS They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too. EOS At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!" EOS From that point on, there was no problem with me signing in church. EOS I think He placed her there for me, also.  It was a mutual deal. EOS There is no one in my congregation at the moment who signs, but I keep hoping for the future. EOS No.  That mission has been placed on my heart. EOS Well... I should be going, but thank you for taking the time to chat. EOS You definitely were.  I am feeling better than I have in about a mo
nth.  I appreciate that. EOS God put you here tonight for a reason EOS Of this I have no doubt. EOS

Hello there, how are you feeling at the moment? EOS Well, not totally terrible, but sad. EOS I used to be really driven to succeed at things. After I graduated college and tried jobs that lasted 1-2 years each at most before I was fired, I gave up believing in most of my abilities to succeed in the workforce EOS Now, even during the pandemic, I have no drive to re-enter the workforce and my family thankfully isn't pushing me to get a job, but I often doubt my self worth because I haven't felt successful at long term goals in a few years EOS Well, the last company I worked at, we were all fired....because the landlord raised the rent so hire on my boss the owner, he couldn't afford to stay there, pre-pandemic EOS In fact most of the jobs I've had, the companies have been sold. In retrospect it's easy for me to realize I should have gone to more stable companies that weren't eventually 
sold EOS Also I suffer from what Google seems to call imposter syndrome EOS Well, I haven't felt the desire I used to feel before the pandemic to go get a new job because I felt burned out working in retail for minimum wage EOS I used to do a lot of charity work as a side hobby to help other people, and sadly, the pandemic kind of spotlit how many of us are struggling and broke, so it didn't exactly feel proper asking to help other peopole in wheelchairs like myself who I'd raise money for to go to adaptive summer camp (kids and adults) - this'll be the 2nd summer in a row where camp is virtual EOS I never wanted to be paid for that charity work btw EOS I wanted to finish writing my autobiography as a poetry book, and slowly, over the last two to three years, I began doubting myself and stopped writing because it seems like the entire American population is so easily upset and make
s everything political EOS I think I WILL eventually follow through with the book....I have to get over the fear of Twitter hating my personal experience even if they dosagree woth me EOS It sure would be, I mean, before the Trump era 5 years ago, I just wanted my dad and sister to have something they could share with future relatives 50 years from now about me n
stead of a sad three paragraph obituary EOS Twitter is the worst, I left there in 2017 I think, and that was a good move. Sadly, everyone seems to be divided on every platform these days. Again, it SEEMS that way even if it really isn't EOS You're right. It's my own fears that ultimately I have to conquer EOS Because let's say I did die (heaven forbid) sometime soon.....I would feel heartbroken taking my last breath knowing that I didn't tell the world what I lived EOS Thanks for your advice / listening. Hello EOS Hi EOS Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever. EOS I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany EOS So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss. EOS This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks. EOS No, my family all moved from the area.  The nearest is now half a country away and hasn't spoken to me in over ten years. EOS It's been... interesting. EOS Ahhh... I hate to be that guy, but I really don't have that many friends.  I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...) EOS I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant. EOS And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was. EOS I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known. EOS I think they forgot about me. EOS The only one I still have contact with is my mother. EOS I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it. EOS I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer. EOS I'm just thankful I have had her this long EOS That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others. EOS Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed... EOS there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do. EOS The look of pride in his face was priceless. EOS The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team. EOS I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language. EOS I am the first signing member of the church. EOS 2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation. EOS I joined just over ten years ago. EOS My church is my anchor. EOS My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted. EOS My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry. EOS If you mean me, I'm male. EOS But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign. EOS Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling. EOS They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too. EOS At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!" EOS From that point on, there was no problem with me signing in church. EOS I think He placed her there for me, also.  It was a mutual deal. EOS There is no one in my congregation at the moment who signs, but I keep hoping for the future. EOS No.  That mission has been placed on my heart. EOS Well... I should be going, but thank you for taking the time to chat. EOS You definitely were.  I am feeling better than I have in about a mo
nth.  I appreciate that. EOS God put you here tonight for a reason EOS Of this I have no doubt. EOS I am actually in the process of studying catechism with my pastor, and plan to be re-confirmed. EOS I was confirmed in a different denomination as a child, but I learned nothing.  One day I realized that I have no knowledge of the faith, and that did not sit well with me. EOS

EOS Each stenographer has their own "Personal Dictionary" which is a list of words in English along with how you in particular write out those words or phrases in steno.  This dictionary is present within the actual steno machine after you transfer it from your laptop to the machine via cable or wifi. EOS Each stenographer has their own "Personal Dictionary" which is a list of words in English along with how you in particular write out those words or phrases in steno.  This dictionary is present within the actual steno machine after you transfer it from your laptop to the machine via cable or wifi.  Thus your machine then knows how you write out words in particular and how to translate those words from steno to English - each stenographer writes a little differently. EOS Yes, exactly!  And it's very important to back up your personal dictionary to the cloud or a seperate drive so that you don't lose it in a hard-drive crash.  A lot of work goes into creating that dictionary!  No, it's happened before, being along for the holidays; but you've helped to cheer me up, so thanks! EOS

Hello EOS Hi EOS Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever. EOS I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany EOS So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss. EOS This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks. EOS No, my family all moved from the area. He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant. EOS And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was. EOS I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known. EOS I think they forgot about me. EOS The only one I still have contact with is my mother. EOS I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it. EOS I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer. EOS I'm just thankful I have had her this long EOS That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others. EOS Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed... EOS there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do. EOS The look of pride in his face was priceless. EOS The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team. EOS I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language. EOS I am the first signing member of the church. EOS 2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation. EOS I joined just over ten years ago. EOS My church is my anchor. EOS My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted. EOS My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry. EOS If you mean me, I'm male. EOS But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign. EOS Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling. EOS They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too. EOS At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!" EOS From that point on, there was no problem with me signing in church. EOS I think He placed her there for me, also.  It was a mutual deal. EOS There is no one in my congregation at the moment who signs, but I keep hoping for the future. EOS No.  That mission has been placed on my heart. EOS Well... I should be going, but thank you for taking the time to chat. EOS You definitely were.  I am feeling better than I have in about a mo
nth.  I appreciate that. EOS God put you here tonight for a reason EOS Of this I have no doubt. EOS I am actually in the process of studying catechism with my pastor, and plan to be re-confirmed. EOS So I am changing that and not just paying lip service to Jesus, but actively seeking Him. EOS Absolutely. EOS I was not always.  I drifted a few years back. Hello EOS Hello, how are you? EOS Stressful, but I have to deal with it. I can't afford to not be present. EOS So i guess the point of this is for me to talk about what it is that I'm facing? EOS I have to have a brave face for everyone because I'm in charge of young people. I have to be strong for them, but it leaves me feeling exhausted EOS I teach special needs students, and they definitely make me happy. It's a very, very rewarding job. However, with political division and COVID, it's hard to reach this population. Parents are not supportive. I feel like I'm being stretched so thin. EOS I'm also a parent, and my son is doing virtual learning, so he's just as isolated. EOS Getting to that mindsight is challenging when the overwhelming feelings of 'failure' loom so heavily. I was seeing a therapist and making great strides, then he informed me that he was moving to a private practice. I cannot afford his sliding scale, and I feel let down. It's just that when one thing starts to go wrong, other things follow. Most of the time I see myself as a positive person that can work through challenging situations, but like you said it's a tough time for everyone EOS Well, I am not one for journaling or anything. I try to stay active. I am about 6 months into remission from stage 4 HL (cancer) and it's been quite the emotional journey there. With that said, the mental and physical overhaul left quite a dent in my overall feelings about myself. I'm just now able to run again and in the past week I ran 2 5k's. To me, this was monumental and made me feel great. I'm also learning how to not overextend myself. I just keep hoping for continued improvement in all areas. The reinforcement is just that I can get through this, these feelings are only temporary. EOS thank you for listening. It helps to sometimes just get it out there. I have to go coach now (virtually). Have a great evening. EOS

and he died on the day after Epiphany EOS So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss. EOS This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks. EOS No, my family all moved from the area. I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...) EOS I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant. EOS And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was. EOS I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known. EOS I think they forgot about me. EOS The only one I still have contact with is my mother. EOS I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it. EOS I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer. EOS I'm just thankful I have had her this long EOS That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others. EOS Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed... EOS there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do. EOS The look of pride in his face was priceless. EOS The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team. EOS I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language. EOS I am the first signing member of the church. EOS 2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation. EOS I joined just over ten years ago. EOS My church is my anchor. EOS My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted. EOS My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry. EOS If you mean me, I'm male. EOS But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign. EOS Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling. EOS They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too. EOS At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!" EOS From that point on, there was no problem with me signing in church. EOS I think He placed her there for me, also.  It was a mutual deal. EOS There is no one in my congregation at the moment who signs, but I keep hoping for the future. EOS No.  That mission has been placed on my heart. EOS Well... Hello EOS Hi EOS Not the best.  I have been quarantined for 5 weeks with COVID-19 (tested positive), so I am getting cabin fever. EOS I am starting to get an aversion to holidays.  When I was in college, my father was dying, and Thanksgiving was the last meal he ate at the family table...
Christmas was the last time he ate solid food,
and he died on the day after Epiphany EOS So I have come to associate Thanksgiving through January as a time of loss. EOS This month has driven it home more, because I have had six people die this month.  It's starting to bring on flashbacks. EOS No, my family all moved from the area. I have a couple people at my church who have checked in, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them friends (we don't hang out, I don't get invited over...) EOS I was in college.  He died slowly and painfully.  It was really unpleasant. EOS And he was a brilliant man.  I could only wish to be half of what he was. EOS I don't even have contact information for them anymore.  The last known phone numbers have been disconnected and the last time I sent mail, it was returned for wrong address, no forwarding information known. EOS I think they forgot about me. EOS The only one I still have contact with is my mother. EOS I avoid comparing myself to others.  I usually come out on the bad side of it. EOS I talk to her regularly.  She is okay, but I fear she is reaching the age where I know I won't have her much longer. EOS I'm just thankful I have had her this long EOS That I do.  While I will never have the skills my father had technically, I am thankful that I did get his ability to be analytical and his compassion for others. EOS Absolutely.  I still remember him teaching me things that I use to this day.  I still smile when I think of one time when he first became ill and couldn't get out of bed... EOS there was a project he wanted to do and it bothered him that it had not gotten done.  Well, I was able to do it, because he had taught me enough to know what to do. EOS The look of pride in his face was priceless. EOS The one thing I carry on because of him is my love for my church.  He was on the church vestry (governing board).  I am on my church worship team. EOS I actually made church history, because I sing with the praise team (some churches call that a choir), but I sing many of the songs in American Sign Language. EOS I am the first signing member of the church. EOS 2021 will be the 50 year anniversary of our congregation. EOS I joined just over ten years ago. EOS My church is my anchor. EOS My pastor is wonderful.  He is like the little brother I didn't have but always wanted. EOS My favorite story about signing in the church is how it began...  I had asked to do it and had been shot down cold six times.  Well, I laugh now, but at the time I was angry. EOS If you mean me, I'm male. EOS But the last time I was told I could not sign for the church, I told the elder who said no that God was going to give him a sign. EOS Well, God delivered on the promise quickly.  That same who  morning we had a family visit who were on a road trip.  They just were passing through but wanted to go to church while travelling. EOS They had a little girl about 6 or 7 years old who was Deaf.  She saw me sitting in the back of the sanctuary signing the lyrics to the songs, and praying in Sign.  Her face lit up and she started signing too. EOS At the end of the service, she found me and gave me a big hug around my legs and then looked up and said "I always wanted to go to a church where someone knew MY language!" EOS From that point on, there was no problem with me signing in church. EOS I think He placed her there for me, also.  It was a mutual deal. EOS There is no one in my congregation at the moment who signs, but I keep hoping for the future. EOS No.  That mission has been placed on my heart. EOS Well...
